Meu filho platinou Rayman Jungle Run no tablet dele. Foi o primeiro e até agora único jogo em que ele conseguiu a façanha: conquistou todas as medalhas possíveis, desbloqueou todos os níveis. Praticamente sozinho (talvez eu tenha vencido uma fase ou outra em um momento de descontração) e demonstrando uma habilidade inacreditável, além da perseverança.

Acreditei que a evolução natural dessa obsessão pelo mundo hilário de Rayman e seus saltos impossíveis estaria no PC.

Infelizmente, uma interface de toque com apenas dois botões é uma coisa e um teclado de PC com 7 funções diferentes é outra completamente diferente. Não platinamos Rayman Origins. Provavelmente jamais conseguiremos. Mas zeramos o maldito com suor, lágrimas e gargalhadas.

Como já fazemos desde Billy Hatcher and the Giant Egg ou mesmo antes disso, dividimos as teclas. Aqui, ele andava e fazia os pulos precisos até o último milissegundo. A mim cabia a tarefa de apertar o botão de ataque quando necessário e o botão de acelerar. Em outras palavras, eu quase sempre ficava apenas olhando o balé de saltos, planadas, escaladas e vitórias do garoto. E derrotas também. Muitas derrotas, muita frustração, muita vontade de fazer birra e xingar os desenvolvedores da Ubisoft de "idiotas". Para respirar fundo e tentar outra vez.

Outra vez.

Outra vez.

Até atingir aquela perfeição que poucos jogos de plataforma exigem e executar a sequência perfeita, no ritmo certo, como se jogador e jogo fossem um só diante dos controles. É um estado mental único. É quase zen, você esvazia o cérebro e seus dedos sabem o que deve ser feito, no momento certo. Sei disso porque em algumas (raras) fases eu substituía meu filho no comando e precisava atingir este equilíbrio interior para triunfar.

Rayman Origins é visualmente um primor e nos traz um mundo mágico e sem sentido, que não precisa fazer sentido para cativar. A música ajuda a entrar naquela frequência cerebral, estimula algum centro obscuro dos neurônios para motivar você a tomar decisões em frações minúsculas de tempo. Você não joga, você praticamente dança, embora não seja um daqueles títulos musicais que a Ubisoft despeja todo ano.

Se você veio aqui pela história, vai se decepcionar. Meu filho e eu vimos o final, revimos o início, relembramos as fases e não conseguimos chegar a uma conclusão sobre do que se trata o jogo. Tem o Rayman, tem seus aliados, tem uns negócios que você precisa juntar para desbloquear outras fases onde você vai juntar mais negócios para chegar nos subchefes, que um dia vão desbloquear o nível final. Se você tiver habilidade e juntar bastante negócios, ativa os níveis secretos. É isso. A fórmula dos jogos de plataforma elevada à sua perfeição minimalista.

A ausência de um enredo plausível aparece até mesmo na cena final, onde tudo retorna rigorosamente ao seu estado inicial. Mas, quer saber? Não faz a menor falta. O bom humor está inserido em cada pixel de cada tela e é impossível não jogar com um sorriso no rosto, mesmo sendo massacrado pela dificuldade galopante.

Foi uma jornada repleta de diversão e camaradagem. Podemos não ter conseguido aquela platina. Mas não vamos esquecer Rayman e seus amigos tão cedo.
 

Originalmente publicada em: http://blog.retinadesgastada.com.br/2015/08/jogando-rayman-origins.html

17449673.review:
It's hard not be charmed by Rayman Origins. It has a sort of party atmosphere, with its bright colors, upbeat music, and surreal shenanigans that keep it charming almost all the way. Almost. The graphics are probably some of the sharpest 2d environments seen in a platformer, with a bizarre cartoony look that's not like much else.

At its heart, Rayman is a collecting platformer, where you try and collect thingies (lums) to free thingies (electoons), though there's a secondary thingie (skull teeth) you can collect in special challenge levels to unlock another thingie (an extra hard series of stages). As such, if you want to hit every note, you'll be repeating stages to make a better time or to collect more thingies, and your opinion on that may very. Overall, though, you don't have to sweat that too much, and those that can put their collection impulses on hold can charge through the game for the most part.

With a variety of moves and skills to unlock, most of the levels become a breezy delight, hovering, running up walls, bouncing off of enemies, etc. In my opinion, it comes very close to dethroning the kings of platforming, save for two issues: the levels can be long, and towards the latter half the game can lean towards being surprisingly tough. Seperately neither of these would be an issue, but together they can deal out some real frustration towards the end of the game. The long levels mean it can lean on being repetitive within a larger world, but each world is varied and often come up with some really great gimmicks, floating through updrafts or sliding down waterfalls. (Note to the developers, though: ice levels where you slide everywhere are not fun.) Annoyingly, the game has a tendency to ask you if you want to switch levels if you die too many times, which it will do over and over - some of the final levels had that pop up occur six or seven times, and when you're just trying to progress, it's rather irritating. An option to turn that reminder off would have been pretty welcome. Contrary to that, though the challenge levels can be similarly tough, their short length and breakneck pace thankfully turn them into one of the highlights of the game. At its best, the game has you charging through areas in a fashion you'd expect of a AAA theme park game, while at no point holding your hand.

Ultimately, though, whether you just get a taste or collect every bit, Origins is worth your time. If you can affort Legends, it's a better game that mitigates many of Origins' flaws, but since Origins is often available for just a few bucks during the seasonal sales, it's absolutely worth it. For those with a distaste for UPlay, you can also relax in the fact Origins doesn't use it at all. It's a rare "pure" sort of game from a big developer, with no DLC shenanigans or anti-piracy measures. (This may also be due to the fact it got a government grant for its development...)

Give it a shot, you should at least get a smile out of it.

16977316.review:
Please, forgive my bad English.
This vote has been one of my hardest decision here on Steam.
I was wondering while playing if this game should deserve a thumb up, but there were too many elements that keep me distant from the quick decision.

I've played the entire game with a gamepad and solo.
I started collecting all the possible rewards, but then I got bored and started to go straightforward.
I've also played a lot of platformer games, so I know a bit about them.

Graphics is superb, with fascinating animations, 3D effects, shaders etc.
Music is super awesome: they change constantly genre and get an amazing atmosphere although the strict change of setting in place.
Also, performance and the stability (even if I had 9/10 bugs during the playtime) of the game is a great point in favor.
The thumb up is due exclusively to this "bright side" of the game.

Now, this is an awesome title. 
There is a big budget behind it, people that liked it (as it seems, a lot of people), and an unending list of people that worked on it.
It is evident how great has been the work behind this title, but still I didn't get why developers decided to develop some strangely annoying mechanics.

So, here are my impressions about the "dark side" of the game:
1) The game environment is unfair:
often, especially during the running part and when the scene dynamically changes its structure, there are a lot of unpredictable dangers that, considering the low field of view and the speed of the dangerous object, you haven't the time to avoid them.
This is the true motivation on why this game is a "frustration game": you must die several times to know the level and then trespass it (and that's why I started avoiding all the collectibles).
There are, also a lot often, enemies that don't act like they do normally but follow a pre-decided path, and often that path is unpredictable and hard to avoid when running or jumping.

2) That heart is mostly unuseful:
Do you remember when platformer's characters had lives?
Just to make an example, in Spyro and Crash there was the possibility to have 3 chances before dying.
The choice of giving to players just one chance before dying is not incorrect. It is nonsensical if the hitbox of the character reactivates after half a second, so you have no time to understand how to save the situation.

3) Hitboxes of the character, enemies and dangerous environment is not clever at all.
There are tentacles that hit you far under the bottom of the drawing and far under the upper; thunders that have a giant invisible hitbox; enemies that I still don't know how far to hit them.
Drawings are very pleasant to see but deceive you from their true collision box.

4) The controls and the physics are not good for a platformer game: 
Maybe, here it'd be appropriate a "last but not least".
Now, I know that lots of people agree that controls are very good and movement are precise and the overall physics is cool.
I think here, maybe, is just a matter of opinion, but at least I want to give a reason to my opinion.
Movement is super smooth, even when not on ice, even when you are in the middle air, and this makes it very imprecise when jumping on platforms.
Running movement is ambiguous: you can start fast and get your movement even more slippery especially in the middle air when you have no more chances to strike a floating platform.
Jumping is decided by the time you press the button, but it has only two values, a high jump and a not-so-short jump, that does not give you the possibility to jump quickly between platforms while running.
When becoming tiny, all the physic changes and gives you a very hard time: lateral attacks are always charged, jumps are even more not precise and you are like constantly on ice.
Gliding with you hairs almost instantly cut down your speed to a constant value, that you can adjust but still with slippery controls. Also, you can't instantly reactivate the gliding, making the flying parts very painful.
Running on curved walls seemed a cool feature, but there are too many parts in wich you must jump to another wall and continue running. I never understood that system as more of half of the times the character started falling down or going backward (on upside-down running).

Without any doubt, this has been one of the most slippery platformers I've ever played since years and those 4 points are why the game should have deserved a bad vote.
Anyway, the work with graphics, music, humor and cuteness saves this game.

And now, let's install Rayman Legends


Update:
I'm playing Rayman Legends and it's absolutely 100 times better than Origins!
All the negative aspects of this title are wiped away, collectibles are fun to take and movements are very precise.

16834901.review:
While I have a great love of platformers (even the old Rayman games), I can't recommend this one. 

The art is gorgeous and it has some good ideas going for it, I hated pretty much every thing else. 

* The control are way too floaty. Platformers should have as close to precise control as possible, especially one as unforgiving as Rayman. 

* On that note, collecting every last collectible bit is a nightmare as many of them are one chance per level. No going back. If you miss it you pretty much have to start the entire level or section over again. Combine that with sluggish, floaty controls and you end up with a game that feels more like a chore than a good time. 

* Slow. The pacing of the entire game is slow. Load screen... level.... tally score.... load screen... map... next level. After seeing it again and again, it starts to feel like a grind.  

Not for everyone.

16759363.review:
Рэйман! С ним я познакомился еще во времена PSone, а так же он стал одной из первых 3х игр на консоли! 
Сейчас же игра приобрела много изменений, стала более разнообразной и, ко всему прочему, тяжелой. Хотя и самая первая игра про Рэймана была не из простых. Правда, в первой части был уклон на изучение английского, что не могло не радовать!
Итак, как всегда, Рэйман со своими чудилами товарищами бездельничали, поплевывая битбокс на деревце, пока своим назойливым чилаутом не накликали бед на свои жoпы. Ну и вот вам начало, фактически, любого платформера. Но любым у меня не поворачивается язык назвать часть Rayman Origins, так как она настолько красиво сделана, что не поиграть в нее - в какой-то степени, грех. Итак, давайте немного о плюсах игры. В первую очередь, это яркое безумие цветовой гаммы, которая будет всегда такой, пока вы не покинете игру и не выйдете на грустный рабочий стол; далее - это чудеснейший OST, который столь подходящий и заставляющий вас делать REPEAT снова и снова (при неудачах, офк), в-третьих - куча всяких побочек, конечно же, в хорошем смысле, а именно - бонусные миссии, возможность играть за других персонажей+открывать новые костюмы (и не только), огромные и надоедливые боссы и, конечно же - раздражительность! 
Да-да! Я последнюю миссию прошел, поди, раза с 100го.... Разбил несколько предметов, которые попались под руку, ибо есть такие уровни, где, затупив на секунду, вы не успеете выполнить задание и умрете.... Так что это вам не просто бродилка, в которой можно вернуться на старт и собрать все ништяки - уровни очень разнообразны и крайне недружелюбны. 
На игру я потратил около 15 часов, далеко не собрав все секретики и пасхалки, так что если вы любите закончить игру на все 100%, то примерно уже можете прикинуть, сколько времени на это уйдет. Так что, если вы не знаете во что поиграть, настоятельно рекомендую эту прекрасную часть Рэймана! Она, уж точно, не скоро затуманится в ваших воспоминаниях. В моих, уж точно! 

9/10

16723689.review:
[h1]Honestly, this is the best video game I have ever played.[/h1]
I first played Rayman Origins on the PlayStation 3, and it quickly won me over with its colorful and fun atmosphere, creative platforming, and above all, THINGS TO COLLECT!

Rayman Origins is a collect-a-thon 2D platformer, giving you multiple things to collect: 
[list]
[*] [b]Lums[/b], which amount to the "coins" of Rayman. These little creatures are typically dormant, but if you wake up a king Lum, all of the Lums in the level will begin to sing and each be worth 2 Lums, but only for a short time. 
[*] [b]Electoons[/b], the "stars" of Rayman. These are collected by reaching certain criteria, which are simply completing the level, collecting 250 Lums in the level, collecting 300 Lums in the level, breaking 2 Electoon cages in the level and freeing the Electoons inside, and completing a time trial run of part of the level. 
[*] [b]Skull Teeth[/b], giant red teeth that belong to the Grim Reaper. These are collected by completing a special stage, 1 in each stage of the game. The stages are unlocked by collecting a certain amount of Electoons. These stages test your reflexes as you chase a treasure chest containing a Skull Tooth. Once all 10 teeth are collected, access to a final hidden stage is granted.
[*] [b]Lum Medals and Time Trophies[/b] are not as important, but are granted for collecting 350 lums and completing the time trial in less than a certain, faster time required for the Electoon, respectively.

 [/list]
The collection in Rayman Origins is incredibly fun and rewarding, with constant indicators of how complete you are with your collection, most notably on your save file. I just can't play this game without getting everything!

Of course, who would want to collect anything if there wasn't any fun platforming involved? Rayman Origins is one of the most creative platformers I've ever played, with multiple power-ups, underwater levels where you can actually swim, levels that involve you flying on the back of a mosquito, running on walls, flying up sandstorms, the list goes on. Everything in the game is fun to go through and puts a smile on my face, which brings me to the graphics.

Rayman Origins was the first game created with Ubisoft's own UbiArt engine, and my, is it gorgeous! Everything in the game is completely hand-drawn: Rayman, his friends, enemies, and especially environments. One of the reasons I bought this game again on Steam was just so I could sit close to my monitor and admire the backgrounds that much more! Everything in the game is happy and colorful, and being sad while playing this game is simply impossible.

The music is also fantastic; as fun and creative as the game it's in, and complements the levels beautifully. 

One warning about this game, however: it does get frustratingly difficult later on. Thankfully, Rayman and his friends have infinite lives, so you can retry levels until you beat them! (or ragequit. Whichever comes first.)

Speaking of Rayman and his friends, one of the best parts of this game's experience is its local co-op. Grab 3 friends and you can embark on the entire game together, collecting Lums (and yes, there is a bit of competition involved in seeing who collects more Lums xD) and struggling through precise platforming while one of your friends keeps messing everyone up. It's loads of fun and the way I first experienced the game!

Finally, Rayman Origins is a gem and a platformer that is not to be missed. Even $10 is a steal for what I honestly believe to be one of the best games ever created, so buy it now!

--Ian PK

16555225.review:
Rayman Origins is just as the name suggests, a return to the origins of the franchise, which started as a 2D platformer, and also brings back a few of the earliest designs and concepts used in the first Rayman game.
I fell in love with Rayman after playing Rayman 2: The Great Escape, and after that, Rayman 3: Hoodlum Havoc.
I never actually played the original Rayman more than the first level, i did not enjoy it, i am not a 2D platformer person.
But since this year marks Rayman's 20th birthday, i decided to play this game, and wanted to actually finish it, which i did.

The game is very enjoyable, even for someone who doesn't really plays 2D platforming games, i can even call it very fun.
It has lots of levels, with different themes, and different playstyle to many of the levels, like running levels, where you must be as fast as possible to reach an enemy/cage/etc, there are shooting levels, where you fly on a mosquito that shoots, plain old classic platforming levels, as well as boss fights, which you must avoid the boss' attacks, and then hit him in a weak spot.
The engine could use some polishing, but it works just fine, except some parts where you might get stuck on a ledge or stuck inside an enemy, but these are pretty rare and not noticable.
The level design is very well done, and requires skill and thought, where you cant just sprint and jump through the obstacles and enemys, and it contains lots of funny and very creative themes to them.
As you progress through the game, you gain abilities like flying, shrinking and diving, and you always end up using one or the other after unlocking them, so kudos to Ubisoft for not forgetting that they implement some features and forgetting to actually make you use them.
the game took me about 10 hours; its not very long but its definately worth its 10 dollar price tag.
I recommend the game to any platforming fan, and ofcourse, Rayman fan, but dont expect anything like the 3D games.

In conclusion, i really like the game, its fun, its intuitive in the current market, and its Rayman, meaning it contains lots of humor and an interesting storyline (although kinda confusing at times).
Its not the Rayman i wanted, but its still very fun.

P.S. it also contains a local co-op options, but since i'm lonely, i couldn't really try it, so i didn't write about it, but i bet it would be lots of fun.

14882500.review:
[h1]Rayman Origins[/h1]
[url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BpvHSy59LPU](I also made a video review if you prefer that format)[/url]

This continuation of the classic platforming Franchise Rayman goes back to it’s origins, as in back to the 2D roots of the first 1995 rayman game.
A lot of Origins’ ingredients were already in that first game: The characters, the electoons, even the mosquito Shmup elements!
Michel Ancel was responsible for the first 2 (very good and successful) games in the series, and was again on board with Ubisoft when the work on Origins 12 years later in 2011 began.

[b]Story and presentation[/b]
Unfortunately, this game has no story (although one might argue that statement) and does not introduce any of the characters so you either have prior knowledge, consult the manual ( that’s no joke!) or the internet.
You are thrown into a cooky world that  looks and sounds great, so much, that it feels like a lovely feverdream on a mix of LSD and amphetamines.
The marriage of Audio and Video is wonderfully executed: Music and sounddesign react to what is happening on screen and are always fitting, fun, pleasent, or - if the situation demands it - exciting, and sometimes even a bit eerie. 
The visuals are stunning and magical and - to me - as impressive as anything realistic or larger than life in modern games.
The eclectic Artstyle creates a “big bowl of crazy” and that is what I personally love most about the game!

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Controls and Leveldesign are on point, tight and fun and  the difficulty is sitting in a nice spot inbetween challenging and almost frustrating.
Yes, the game is pretty hard at times. I sometimes found myself repeating one little section of a level a dozen times until I started to get aggravated and cursed at the screen... but It happended rarely and because of a lack of concentration mostly! 

Every level can be completed by just making it through, or by collecting a certain number of collectibles to get the maximum number of medals for that level. 
One can also try to beat a certain time to get a speed run medal which is asking for precision platforming.
Then there are the crazy treasure chest runs which are levels in which you chase a treasure chest and have to be as fast as possible.
These levels require a lot of practice and trial and error progression which could bother many, I liked them and found myself more frustrated with some of the standard levels and bosses... but that might be a question of individual taste.

I beat the game in around 11 hours and it will give you at least 15 to 20 hours of gameplay if you target 100% completion.
I personally felt the game was a little too long, halfway through when you think you have completed the game, 4 new worlds pop up with a boss in each of them, these bosses are mainly fun but can get a little frustrating sometimes because of trial and error pattern learning on the players part.
The leveldesign got better the further you progress in the game, I felt, but still it seemed a little stretched for my taste and schedule but most people would probably disagree.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
If you like challenging platformers and the Rayman art style you will definitely enjoy this game a lot!
It’s not on par of course with SMW. It’s not on par with Super Meat Boy although that is a bad comparison for many reasons.
But it’s certainly the best platformer I played since Super Meat Boy and I will definitely play through the follow up Rayman Legends when I get the chance.
Last but not least, the game supports up to 4 player local co-op which is really fun!
I would recommend this game (I even gifted my little niece a copy for her 3DS last christmas, so there you go)!

14810570.review:
其实这是我接触的第一部雷曼系列作品，然后我就喜欢上了雷曼系列。
       本作是一款2D横板过关游戏，回归系列最初的游戏模式。清新的画风，出色的音效与音乐，再配上雷曼和伙伴们滑稽的动作，无不让我沉醉在雷曼的世界之中。游戏的美工实在是太赞了！将丛林、沙漠、海底、山地等场景呈现在屏幕上，勾画出了美丽的雷曼世界。当然，能做出如此效果，育碧的UBI art framework引擎也是功不可没。
      关卡设计上，游戏本身也不只局限于单纯的横板过关，当角色坐上蚊子一般的生物面对敌人时，就变成了横向的弹幕射击游戏；而当面对诱人的宝箱时，游戏的节奏骤然加快，变成了跑酷追逐战，就要你眼疾手快了；当面对巨大的BOSS时，就需要你开动脑筋，寻找弱点，并把握住机会击败敌人了。此外，大部分关卡自带time attack模式，让你即使在通关后也可以继续挑战自己。   不过，就算没有该模式，关卡中光子的收集也会让你暗下决心，多次挑战，只为达到圆满的吧。
      随着场景的变换，游戏的难度会逐渐增加，你会慢慢发现来自制作人的恶意。本作的总体难度是高于最新作传奇的，这也是游戏更加具有挑战性。不过个人认为这还是值得的，在克服一道又一道关卡后，你会很有成就感。本人因为难度和强迫症已经怒摔手柄多次，不过终于通关那一刻，感觉那真是太棒了。好像又回到了小时候玩红白机的日子。
      另外个人觉得手柄的游戏体验比较好，有条件的话就配一个吧。
      如果要说缺点的话，个人觉得就是没有线上内容或者成就系统，以及一些令人发指的关卡了。
      雷曼系列算是育碧最后的良心了，作为育碧第一款比较成功的系列作品，雷曼几乎从没让人失望过。育碧，好好珍惜这系列吧，别毁了它了。你已经没有多少招牌可以再继续毁了。

"Origens do Homem Raio" é um platformer 2D sidescrolling em que você controla Rayman e seus parceiros. Apesar de claramente ser um jogo inspirado em New Super Mario Bros Wii, ele tem toda uma identidade própria e é igualmente divertido. Dá pra tranquilamente jogar sozinho ou com mais 3 pessoas em coop local. Animações bastante fluídas e hilárias, trilha sonora empolgante e variada (com ritmos inspirados em country, bossa nova, música mexicana, entre outros), mundos com temáticas diversificadas e visual bonitão são alguns dos elementos de destaque aqui. Achei melhor de controlar os personagens em um direcional digital em vez de analógico, pois este pareceu pouco responsivo em relação àquele. Não há sistema de vidas e a maioria das fases conta com checkpoints, mas nem por isso tem pouca dificuldade. Os estágios basicamente se dividem em três tipos: plataforma normal, shoot-em-up (no qual você sobe em um mosquito gigante e atira nos inimigos) e perseguição de um baú anbulante até o final (são as mais difíceis no geral, pois exigem mais precisão nos movimentos). Os objetivos nas fases não se limitam a passar delas: você pode tentar coletar o máximo de Lums possível, terminar em tempo recorde ou ainda achar as câmaras secretas onde você tem que salvar umas criaturinhas (as mesmas que ficam presas também no final dos estágios). À medida que você vai jogando, fadinhas concedem ao Rayman novas mecânicas, como subir em paredes, golpear inimigos e o planar com os cabelos (clássico!). O jogo possui um final normal e um especial, no qual você precisa ter capturado as joias dos 10 baús ambulantes, debloqueando uma fase nova, maiorzinha e mais difícil, além de contar com um chefe. Então se você curte um jogo de plataforma com jogabilidade mais retrô, mas com características audiovisuais de atualmente, ou quer se divertir localmente com amigos, recomendo!

Obs: eu sei que Rayman Legends, sucessor deste jogo, possui 2/3 das fases do Origins como extra, mas resolvi ir neste porque não queria deixar de experienciar o 1/3 cortado.

14054159.review:
It's a Rayman game (I loved the first one on PS1), it's often good, sometimes great... so why I am so bored when I play it ?

Two expressions come to my mind to try to get to describe the feelings i have regarding this game: "Soulless" and "Paint-by-numbers".

Many of the levels feel empty. You go from platform to platform, you meet some enemies, but most of them are immobile, or even sleeping. They don't feel like enemies at all, they are not here to hunt you, they don't care about you at all. They completely lack personality. Good platformers have enemies that have an interesting behavior that give them personality. Even Goombas in Mario are memorable with their mean looking eyes. In Rayman, in many cases, that's not the case. It's so bad that sometimes it's hard to tell if something is here to help you or kill you (i made a few mistakes that way).

Story-wise it's the same. It's full of holes. After a hilarious 5 min cartoon intro, the game tells you "ok you have to fetch electoons again. Go for it". It's almost like there is no relation to what you just saw with what you have to do. Most of the characters you will meet have no name, and will usually don't utter more than one sentence. Sometimes it feels like there are 2 distinct stories and none of them was completed.

That's really disappointing, because technically the game is top notch, with colorful environments and very nice animations. And sometimes, the Rayman's magic is back. In a few levels, (particularly the water world levels), enemies actually have personality, the environments are full of life, and the music nicely complement the action.

Nowadays AAA studios have mostly abandoned platformers to the indie scene. So i was happy to get a new Rayman from a big Ubisoft studio. I suspect many of you feel the same.

However, I can't forget nor forgive the fact that, after 2 or 3 levels, i usually quit the game because i was bored. Worse, i also used the "skip level" functionality several times when i didn't feel like completing that level right away. That's not things i would get in a good game. I did finish the game, including the awesome bonus level (by far, the best level, and really enjoyable), but i really had to force myself to play many of the levels (particularly the wind world).

Sadly, there are too many boring levels where I'm just going through the motions. "Been there, done that", was a recurring feeling. Most levels felt like the 1000th iteration on the same stuff from countless platformers. There are too few memorable/good levels for me to recommend this game.

Maybe some of the problems come from the added multiplayer. I only played the game solo, and i guess with friends, it would get more chaotic, but also more fun. Maybe that would alleviate some of the issues i had with the game. It would explain why the levels sometimes feel empty and the enemies are too passive: with 4 players it must already be very hard to get to the end with everyone. But I'm unable to test that theory.

PS : For achievements hunters, be warned that the game doesn't include Steam achievements, even though the console versions have them.

PS2 : Regarding difficulty. Some reviewers state that this game is the toughest game they've ever seen. That's not my opinion. 2D Platformers have often been challenging games. Considering that fact, i think that Origins is not easy, but it's not hard either. 

If you just want to see the end, as well as unlock the bonus level, Rayman Origins is way easier than many platformers from the 90s, like the SNES platformers, or Rayman 1 on PS1. It's also way easier than some modern titles like Super Meat Boy. If you're familiar with platformers, you should be able to finish it without issue.

Time trials are probably trickier, but i wasn't interested in trying them so i can't give you my opinion on them.

I don't often enjoy single-player games. However, i was excited to play this, as the Rayman franchise has always had a special place in my heart.

The Rayman series have done a great job at going back to their platformer roots. The platformer Rayman games are arguably even more enjoyable than classics, such as Rayman 3.

Gameplay:
Loads of worlds and levels, all with a their own unique theme. Even after finishing the game, you can still unlock new things and collect more items, which gives it an exceptionally long lasting appeal. Controls are smooth, far more natural than most platformers on PC. Gameplay is fast-paced, but never too fast to keep up. 9/10 on this part.

Graphics:
Prime example of graphics taking a game to new heights. Each level looks gorgeous. Every little detail has been carefully made. Animations are smooth.
10/10 for this part.

Sound: 
Catchy soundtrack, cute voices and sound effects. Not much to say, really. 8.5/10.

Overall, this game is an excellent addition to anyone's game library. One of the best platformer games of the past decade. 
9.5/10.

13898225.review:
Rayman Origins revives a character we have maybe not actively seen in games for some time now. When I was growing up, Rayman was my absolute hero. I will never forget Rayman 3, and Rayman 2, where colourful characters came to life and took me on amazing adventures. Rayman Origins however goes back to old, old Rayman games, in which the character is barely larger than a pen and often finds himself dodging household utensiles. 

Rayman as a character is a colourful little guy without arms or legs, who can make a helicopter out of his hair and traditionally throws his fist at enemies. He is often assosciated with his best friend Globox, a blue frog who loves to dance raindances.

Rayman Origins creates a beautifully colourful world, with fun music and great level design. The art in this game is absolutely amazing, and it all comes together in such a delightfully colourful way that it is a real joy to play through the levels. 
It is also notable that Rayman Origins is a very quick paced jump'n'run, and when you find yourself used to the completely adaptable controls, you can go through a level with great momentum, never really stopping for anything. This makes the levels even more fun, as once you replay them and get the hang of them, you can just glide through them, reminding me very much of the old slide levels. 

The game is quite replayable (as I just noticed myself by returning to the game after some time). You can free 5 Lums in every level, and whilst it is not necessary for game completion to get all these Lums, you can unlock new stuff and further levels by getting them all. It is therefore worthwhile to repeat older levels and look cloer for the cages of the Lums, or collect more points throughout every game.

There is not much of a story to the game, as expected maybe of a simple jump and run game, but generally the characters are charming and the environment is so friendly and vibrant that the story is not so much necessary.

My only gripe with the game is, that, as a longtime rayman fan, i find myself not recognizing the main character very much. To me, Rayman had always made a friendly, confident, cool expression, where as in Rayman Origins he very much becomes a tongue-stuck-out crazy silly kind of guy.
The game goes for a very silly reprensetation of the characters, which is certainly fun in the general feel of the game.
What is completely missing however is Rayman's traditional fist throwing mechanic. This came as a disappointment to me because I was so used to using this special,personal technique in most of his other games. Rayman no longer throws fists, instead he kind of just slaps his enemies, or tornadoes through them, or kicks them, or stamps them, which is all very fun, but I miss his trademark technique. 

Overall I can absolutely recommend this game. If you can ever get it in a sale and maybe get it for a bit cheaper, it is definitly worth it. Lovely Art, lovely Music, fun and unique level design, charming characters, definitly replayable, even if you dont have a lot of time on your hand. Quick paced and lively. Whilst it is not the continuation of the rayman franchise that I had maybe hoped for, it is certainly a great Jump'n'run more like the very old original rayman games.

Acho que é um dos jogos de plataformas mais legais que lançaram nos ultimos tempos, achei bem mais legal que aqueles Mario "2D" por exemplo, especialmente pq o Rayman lembra mais o estilo do Donkey Kong Country (SNES) que considero um dos melhores desse estilo.

Não sou muito fã do character design do jogo, acho o Rayman legalzinho mas a maioria dos outros personagens considero  algo bem tosco, tanto na aparencia como no conceito... mas acho que esse é o unico defeito que conseguiria apontar pq fiquei MUITO fã do visual geral do jogo (cenários e efeitos), das músicas que são absurdamente bem feitas e encaixam muito bem com as fases, do estilo de gameplay, do desafio das fases e etc o jogo é incrivelmente "redondo" na sua execução, ficando aquele ar de produto completo e bem feito.

Hoje em dia não tenho mais tanto animo pra jogar esse tipo de jogo (plataforma com colecionaveis e etc) por horas sem dar uma enjoadinha igual na época do SNES/Mega Drive que ficava na fissura até fazer 100%, mas mesmo jogando Rayman "casualmente" me diverti muito, realmente da gosto de jogar e é daqueles jogos que você morre 30 vezes numa parte mas não se sente frustrado pq tem uns checkpoints bem justos (e ai entra o lado do level design que é muito bem feito) e o fluxo do jogo não fica interrompido, mesmo que tenha algum desafio mais complicado lá no meio.

Outro ponto legal é que o jogo nem tem muita "história", não que ter história seja ruim mas hoje em dia tem muito jogo que a história só esta lá pra ficar de "filler" pq no fim é algo totalmente desnecessário (e várias vezes sem graça demais), no Rayman a coisa é bem direta: tem uma apresentação bem simples e rápida e depois só umas coisinhas bem breves sobre o que esta acontecendo, 95% do resto do jogo é puro gameplay e é nisso que ele se garante.

Nem parece um jogo dessa Ubisoft que hoje em dia só faz cagada, um sonho seria a Sega fazer um Sonic com a mesma qualidade que esse jogo tem.

13566784.review:
Bueno otro análisis mas,empecemos:

Jugabilidad: En este titulo de plataformas con perpesctiva en scroll lateral,el manejo básico es correr y saltar,aprendiendo otra serie de movimientos y "poderes"conforme vayamos completando niveles.
Esta gama de habilidades que vamos aprendiendo a lo largo del juego, está intimamente relacionada con los niveles.según aprendamos ciertos movimientos,los niveles siguientes estarán construidos de tal forma que podamos aprovechar esa nueva habilidad para recorrerlos y completarlos.

Añadir que a parte de los niveles principales de scroll lateral,el juego cuenta en cada mundo con un nivel bonus donde tendremos que perseguir un cofre para ir consiguiendo dientes,que posteriormente al tenerlos todos nos desbloquearán un nivel extra.También decir que en cada mundo suele haber una fase de shoot em up lateral con rayman montado en un mosquito.
Podremos elegir otro personaje a parte de rayman a lo largo de la aventura,pero es algo meramente estético,ya que en el apartado jugable nada cambia de manejar un personaje u otro.

Graficos:En este sección el titulo se muestra con un estilo cartoon para recrear todo el mundo de rayman,pudiendo crear la falsa idea que es un juego para niños.Pero mas bien usa esta estética como claro homenaje a otra época,donde este genero era el rey.A pesar de tener ese estilo de dibujo animado e intentar parecer de otro tiempo,el juego se favorece de los avances técnicos de hoy día y digamos lo así,todo se ve en perfecto HD.

Sonido:La banda sonora acompaña y ambienta cada nivel perfectamente según lo requiera la ocasión.
Los efectos sonoros son desenfadados y divertidos,ayudando así un poco mas a lo que esta orientado el titulo enteramente:divertir.

Juego precioso,cuidado en todo sus apartados al mas mínimo detalle,con una curva de dificultad bastante bien echa y admitiendo todo tipo de jugador,un homenaje a otra época y otra manera de entender los videojuegos. Echo con mas intención artística y de cariño a los videojuegos y homenajearlos,que desde un punto de vista mercantil,y así salen obras como esta...un juegazo

Mi nota:9.5

13338221.review:
For the longest time, I felt rather odd around this game. I never bothered to buy this rather affordable title for years since it came out, and despite its popularity, I just didn't feel like getting it for some reason. Then one day, a sale came around, and as I was looking around for bargins, I came across this title for a nice little price. I was torn between a few other titles I wanted, but then I decided to get out of my comfort zone and try something I never was too interested in. 

Turns out it was worth it, even if it ticked me off near the end.

In an age full of mindless shooters, zombie surviver deathmatches, and "retro" games that hardly feel retro and more lazy in the art department, Rayman Origins is a game that shows us that you don't need any of that rubbish to be a good game. You can be a 2D platformer and still look good at the same time, and best of all, it has difficulty that scales with the levels, so the further you go, the harder things get. None of that so called "hardcore" platforming crap where they claim they designed the levels poorly intentionally. 

Ranting aside, this truely is a nice return to form for Rayman, even if the story is rather confusing and the gameplay, while it starts out fun and simple at first, soon gets really hard and demanding as more mechanics come into play, sometimes to the point that you die over and over again at a single point of the game until you either master it or get lucky.. But thankfully, there are plenty of save points, so it at least reduces the frustration, even near the end of the game.

Now, the game isn't perfect, sure. As I said earlier, sometimes you'll come across levels that'll kick you in the balls over and over again, turning your happy little mood into a mood of pure annoyance, if not rage due to the near-percise actions needed for some parts of the game (as one person noted, it is almost like a quick time event, but without the "Press x to not die" system in place). However, as pissed off as I would get at these levels, I still powered through, and even if you couldn't, the game will allow you to skip some levels if they prove too hard for some players, which is a kind gesture I suppose, if sometimes insulting. 

In short, while I don't recommend this to casual gamers, those looking for a real, honest challenge might find this a lovely title to invest in. And best of all, you can play with your friends, should you have any, which might make the game easier or harder, depending on if your friends are jerks or not.

Play this game through to the end, and you will find yourself slowly driven mad as you realise the game's level design is actually a sinister ploy to make you lose your grip, over and over, in your attempt to reach the exit. It might start out with a hand on your shoulder and some encouraging words to help you along, but before you know it you find yourself thrown off the metaphorical cliff as you reset the same stage for the twentieth time in order to bypass the same obstacle, while the game gives you a patronizing pat on the back and asks if you don't want to just give up already.

Pretty game, the visuals are a work of art, but the level designers were a band of sadistic bastards beyond compare.

Rayman sempre foi um jogo muito bom, desde os primeiros lançamentos até os atuais. Rayman Origins trata-se d eum jogo plataforma.

Este jogo basicamente tem um enredo bem simples, tão simples que parece mais até um conceito. Rayman e seus amigos estão dormindo e roncando, fazendo muito barulho, os outros não conseguem dormir, sendo assim, os bixos uma hora surtam e capturam eles. Voce escapa e o jogo começa.

Rayman Origins é um jogo platforma, ao estilo Mario e SOnic mesmo, mas com seu próprio carater. Voce pode andar, correr, pular atacar, nadar, mergulhar, planar. Para vencer os inimigos basta pular encima deles, ou atacalos. O jogo também possuí algun tipos de ataques diferentes. É possível fazer wall jump. O jogo pode ser jogado em coop local em até 4 jogadores. Detalhe que no coop tem friendly hit, embora não leve dano, atrapalha.

As músicas do jogo, são muito boas, de certa forma são marcantes, combina muito com a temática do jogo.

Os cenários são muito bonitos, e bem desenhados, além de possuir alguns secrets.

Os gráficos são 2D carttonizados. É bem bonito e admiravel.

Sem bugs ou glitchs.

Em uma maneira bem facil de entender, basicamente, se voce gosta de jogos como Mario, Sonic, Little Big Planet, etc, então, voce também vai gostar desse jogo. Caso contrario, acho melhor deixar quieto então. Em todo caso, eu recomendo o jogo!

11713440.review:
O que era para um jogo que peguei só para me distrair entre dois jogos mais longos, esperando uma experiência curta e tranquila, provou-se ser algo completamente diferente, e de forma positiva. Segundo o steam, demorei umas 20 horas para fechar e o jogo provou ser muito mais difícil que a maioria dos "AAA" no mercado, principalmente depois que você passa da primeira parte do jogo.

O principal destaque do jogo vem logo de cara: Os gráficos. Os gráficos do jogo já são conhecidos e são extremamente belos, graças a engine UbiArt, com personagens e cenários pintados a mão. Mas mais do que gráficos, em geral a jogabilidade, level design e trilha sonora também se destacam bastantes. O jogo é fluidíssimo e os controles respondem muito bem (na maior parte do tempo). O level design é simples, direto e adaptado para speed runs. Por fim, a trilha sonora é recheada de melodias memoráveis que vão ficar presas na sua cabeça por algumas semanas. 

É um jogo que começa devagar e bem fácil, que vai lhe ensinando habilidades novas e apresentando novos desafios aos poucos. Porém, nos partes mais avançadas, a dificuldade remete muitas vezes aos plataformas oldschool da era 16 bit's. Na maior partes das vezes é um ponto positivos, mas que em algum momento pode-se apresentar um tanto frustrante quando os controles podem não responder bem nesses momentos, ou quando o Level Design fica demasiadamente focado em tentativa-erro. (ou seja, você sabe que vai morrer, mas com decoreba consegue passar de boa). Infelizmente, os chefes não são grandes coisas, por serem 100% nesse estilo.

Mas tirando um defeito aqui e ali, é um jogo que de certo me surpreendeu, e me trouxe de volta os tempos de plataforma oldschool: Desafiante, carismático e viciante.

Il gioco di per se è bello, i livelli ed i personaggi sono tutti disegnati a mano, una meraviglia per gli occhi, sopratutto a risoluzioni oltre il full hd.

11494045.review:
On le pensait perdu depuis les Lapins Crétins, le souvenir amer en tête d'une promesse de Murphy que l'on a longtemps pensée vaine : "A bientôt dans Rayman...euh...quatre ?". Des années plus tard, la parole de la grenouille mi-mouche aura enfin été honorée, le tout dans un retour aux sources, à la belle 2D en guise de cerise sur le gros cake. Une [i]magnifique[/i] 2D. Si ce n'était pour quelques boss mal animés dont la raideur est trahie par les gros plans, si ce n'était pour un manque de vie et de finesse des traits à la loupe que seuls les pires raclures difficiles au-delà du raisonnable auront remarqué, on se croirait dans un dessin animé.

Exit la rondeur et la féérie du premier épisode, bonjour les triangles, les langues qui pendent et le délire cartoonesque. Différent mais incroyablement proche et fidèle à son ancêtre et à ses suites, Rayman Origins satisfait sur tous les tableaux. Et quels tableaux ! Aussi variés que n'importe quel plateformer qui se respecte, ils sont un émerveillement à parcourir pour le joueur bercé par des musiques qui savent parfois être d'une beauté à t'en caresser l'oreille. Langoureusement. Amoureusement. Ou d'un rythme amusant à t'en tapoter le cul pour te faire avancer plus vite, selon les situations. Harmonie j'écris ton nom. Origins est visuellement et musicalement impeccable.

Le gameplay, paraissant souffrir de quelques imprécisions au premier contact, cèdera vite à la fermeté du joueur qui fera tout ce qu'il veut de son pantin Rayman. La difficulté est progressive et bien pensée, laissant les promeneurs qui ne sont venus que pour un gentil plaisir traverser l'aventure sans trop d'accrocs mais offrant aux accros du 100% une vraie résistance. Seuls un menu et une carte du monde étrangement fades, à plus forte raison quand on a en mémoire la merveille de mappemonde du tout premier Rayman, atténuent le charme qui nous envoûte.

On peut dire qu'on l'aura attendu celui-là, mais au bout du tunnel, le bonheur. Avec un peu de chance Jade et Pey'j emboîteront le pas du nain jaune désarticulé et honoreront eux aussi leur promesse.

11116046.review:
I only sort of recommend this game... The graphics, music and level designs range from good to amazing, that alone makes it well worth playing, but... (There's always a but.) The controls and boss designs leave much to be desired. Bosses move in completely fixed patterns that are pretty unforgiving and extremely boring once you know the patterns. In other words, bosses are trial and error until you've learned the patterns. That gets tedious real fast --- especially so on the final boss, where the bad controls and poor boss design clash in such a way that it's actually possible to go too fast and die because of that, which seems counter-intuitive when you're chasing the bad guy. The same thing goes for a few other levels, where you can build up enough momentum that the game can't keep up, which is extremely sad to have happen in a platformer. And then there are the controls that don't really feel tight enough for many situations that you are put in. Constantly I caught myself thinking "this wouldn't be a problem if it was Super Meat Boy or Mega Man". It's not that the controls are downright bad, they're just not good enough.

If you can overlook the flaws, it's a very good and extremely entertaining game.

VOTO GLOBALE:.......9/10

"Un platform ben sviluppato e divertente, dotato di un comparto grafico semplicemente meraviglioso. Immergendoci nel magico mondo di Rayman Origins ci si ritrova con la sensazione di avere per le mani un prodotto ad un passo dall'essere un capolavoro, che vorrebbe proporre una doppia interpretazione, adattandosi ad un pubblico di novizi, ed allo stesso tempo un’esperienza platform ricca e profonda per i giocatori più stagionati. Purtroppo il titolo non riesce pienamente né in un senso né nell’altro, non permettendo ai primi di arrivare all’end-game mentre i secondi troveranno il livello di sfida della prima metà piuttosto blando. Ciò incide negativamente sulla longevità, comunque arricchita dall'assortimento di collezionabili da scovare, operazione incentivata dai vari livelli sbloccabili. 10817868.review:
Given that i'm usually the idiot that writes the reviews with 10,000 ratings with something dumb and nonsensical, I figured i would actualy write a constructive review for once for a game that I actually like. 

Rayman: Origins is an interesting game in that it is a platformer with a non human protagonist not made by Nintendo in an era where the modus operandi is generally stamping out 3rd person shooters with crewcut white boy protagonists with perplexingly green 5 o' clock shadows. The asthetic of the game is striking to say the least and it is impossible to mistake for another game. Brown and grey are simply not colors that exist in this worlds pallet and it makes everything feel bright and alive. For the proper enjoyment I would abandon the "gotta go fast" mentality that plagues many fans of the genre, and take a slightly slower pace to enjoy the lovely atmosphere and music. Also avoid the power ups that double your electoon count unless you really like listening to the same 12 note song every 20 seconds of game play. 

To put it simply: It is a nice game with a nice pace that doesn't outstay its welcome with an undersated soundtrack and visual design.

10683900.review:
At it's core, a 2D platformer. A few mechanics beyond running, jumping and attacking are unlocked as you progress - swimming , wall running, flying - however they're mostly only used in the world that you unlocked them in. 

The combat is very simple, most enemies die in one hit, apart from the bosses which have some originality, but like much of the harder portions of the game, the bosses just need lots of repetition to get muscle memory and knowledge of attack patterns. 

Each level has a few "electoons", which are mostly quite easy to acquire. The fun part in getting these is in the little challenge each section presents, but due to limited game mechanics, I can't remember any distinct ones.

The hard parts, such as bosses and the levels where you chase a treasure chest for a secret *thing*, are like quick time events without the visual cues - and if you're just a moment off even though you made a good recovery, the design of the game forces you to play again, getting a microsecond closer to the speed they want you to get to.

The visuals are quite nice, but you only notice them in the calm before the storm because otherwise you're too busy running around or trying to not die, which is a shame. 

The music was unique, but the loops caused by dying repeatedly mean that any nice melodies are quickly forgotten. 

The sidescrolling shooter parts are fun and a good challenge, and there aren't too many, which means you can accept that they didn't give the separate costumes (oops, I mean characters) distinctive playstiles. 
As far as I noticed, even in the walking part of the game, the different characters did nothing either, apart from help you identify you and your friends apart.

Without co-op I probably wouldn't enjoyed this game enough to bother going very far. Co-op mechanics were decent and allowed for coordination and teamwork, however guacamelee did it better - in fact, I think Guacamelee did everything better, apart from on incomparable things such as artstyle.

tl;dr unless you're a big Rayman fan, play Guacamelee instead.

9830782.review:
One of the best platformers I have ever played. The Donkey Kong Country series was the one I always considered the best, until I tried this one. The main thing I like about this game, is that you move at a much faster pace, compared to something like the DKC games. There are optional challenge levels that will test just how good you are at controlling your character at its max speed. If you can complete those, you earn the right to play the Land of the Livid Dead level, which is the most challenging stage in the game. 

All the secret/bonus rooms in a stage, have their own unique platforming segments that you must get past, in order to get the reward from it. I enjoy that a lot more than how the DKC bonus/secret areas usually are (just collecting the bananas). The boss fights are also a lot more difficult and better designed. The art and animations make the boss fights look so good and those water stages also.

The difficulty is also great. Nothing is cheap and unfair. Everything stays the same for a stage and you will never feel like it was the stage's fault for dieing, but your own. The game also has fast respawns for when you die and automatic checkpoints per stage. You will never have to start back at the beginning of the stage (unless you die there) and you will get to keep everything you have collected so far.

The game will last you 10+ hours, if you plan on trying to unlock all the levels. If you like this game, then check out Rayman Legends, which I think is even better.

Roughly speaking, you can think of this game as a modern Super Mario Bros. Sometimes you have to race to the end, most of the time you have to kill bad guys and jump through figurative hoops to make it to the end of the level. Many maps are quite random and weird, but superbly fun nonetheless.

9588336.review:
Rayman Origins is a platform game. 

A reboot of the classic Rayman game (the 2D one, not the 3D games), Rayman Origins is an excellent addition to the franchise. 

Rayman and his friends are all relaxing on the Snoring Tree. But their snoring disturbs an old granny from the Land of the Livid Dead. She sends out an army of Darktoons across the Glade of Dreams, who capture the Electoons which inhabit it. You, as Rayman and his friends, must go out across the world and free the Electoons to restore the Glade. 

Although the story is great, the game's aesthetics and soundtrack is where it really shines. The beautifully crafted world, accompanied by the brilliant musical score, is what really sucked me in. The visuals are absolutely gorgeous, and the soundtrack is superb. 

Gameplay is excellent too. The animations are fab, and the game overall feels very fluid. I am not a huge fan of platformers, the gameplay usually fails to entertain me, but I absolutely adored Origins. You start off with just the ability to run. But as you progress you unlock more abilities, such as wall-running. There are also certain levels in which you ride a mosquito. You can either shoot enemies or suck them up to fire them. 

The game comes with 4-player local co-op. This is great, but it would be even better if it included Online play too. This is the only downside to the game. 

One of the best PC games to be released in 2012. I recommend this to both those who adore platformers, and those who do not.

9570027.review:
Hilarious fun for 1-4 players. This game isn't plagued by some of the annoying aspects of platformers like Mario. 

There is no timer except during an optional (but highly recommended) second level run during which you try to achieve a time goal. The lack of a timer allows you to explore as much as you like without feeling pressured. Also, one of the most annoying things about Mario games is absent from Rayman -- collision detection between players. In Mario, you feel forced to stay clear of your co-op partner as much as possible because bumping into him or accidentally jumping on his head (or visa versa) usually sends you flying uncontrollably to your death. In Rayman, there is no collision between players except when the players choose to boost each other or intentionally slap each other. There are no "continues" in Rayman. You're not going to have to start the game over because you run out of them. If it takes you 10,000 lives to finish a level, then so be it.

I had to restart several levels simply because I was laughing to hard to play. The game is downright hilarious, and the platforming is challenging without being irritating. 

10/10

9556740.review:
Fan du premier Rayman, je ne me suis pas pressé pour jouer à ce nouvel épisode, car je pensais que celui-ci empruntais la route du design et de l'ambiance plus "crétin" instaurés avec les lapins crétins.

Certes le tout est globalement plus "idiot" dans le concept, mais ça s'arrête là, on retrouve vraiment l'univers Rayman de part les créatures et les mondes visités.

J'ai acheté ce jeu tardivement, sans attendre grand chose, et c'est pourtant une véritable claque que je me suis pris.
Ce jeu est quasiment parfait à TOUS les niveaux:

Les graphismes sont sublimes, tout comme les animations, et les mondes variés et originaux.
Retrouve toujours cette double association des mondes qui était déjà propre au premier Rayman (une thématique géographique/environnementale + une thématique culturelle).

Le gameplay est excellent, et très fluide et varié, le level design est juste sublime et calibré pour le speed run jouissif.

Les musiques...raaaah les musiques, juste à la fois enchanteresses et rigolotes.
Le seul soucis avec les musiques c'est qu'elles font toutes plus dans le format " chansons humoristiques remplies d'onomatopées" que vraies mélodies à la Rayman 1 (chose corrigée dans Rayman Legends).

La durée de vie est très importante vu le nombre de niveaux et de défis divers pour tout terminer à 100%, et le challenge progressif est équilibré tout le long du jeu, pour tout type de joueurs (les hardcore gamers s'y retrouveront.

Ce Rayman Origins rentre on compétition avec DK Returns au titre de meilleur jeu de plateforme de ces dernières années.
Aussi fan de DK que je puisse être, je suis forcé d'admettre que Rayman Origins est un meilleur jeu que DK Returns, car même si les deux titres sont à égalité dans presque tous les domaines, Rayman bat pourtant à plate couture notre gorille préféré sur les critères de la maniabilité (inertie trop importante dans DK, et satanée WiiMote à secouer...) et de la bande son (peu mémorable dans DK).

En bref Rayman Origins est ma plus grosse claque vidéo-ludique de ces dernières années (avec Rayman Legends), rien que ça !!!


* Points forts :

+ C'est magnifique !
+ La patte artistique
+ L'univers enchanteur et humoristique
+ Fidèle à l'esprit Rayman d'origine
+ Bande son superbe
+ Gameplay au poil
+ Level Design Hallucinant
+ Challenge équilibré
+ Les mondes variés
+ La durée de vie


* Points faibles :

- Musiques de qualité mais trop dans le style onomatopées humoristiques
- Pas de coop online



19/20

9444250.review:
I'm a huge fan of 2D platformers, and Rayman Origins is one of the best I've played in years. It's right up there with Super Mario World and DKC Returns. The addition of 4-player co-op just serves to make the game even more fun with more people. The level design is brilliant and challenging. 

Though you are given unlimited lives, the game manages to have some challenging moments, even for a platforming veteran. While challenging, the game never feels unfair. When you die, you feel as though it was your fault.

The graphics, while not technically spectacular are impressive. The little details you can see help to make every moment look incredible.

Plus they finally pulled off underwater stages without feeling slow.

9087938.review:
I love this game.

I never got past the control setups though so I'm not sure if I missed anything. That part was REALLY hard. I even went online to find solutions and I tried all of them. I'm not going to spoil it for everyone, but it involves **SPOILER** making sure your controller is plugged in before starting **SPOILER**

And I'm STILL stuck trying to configure my gamepay. Holy shit this is a tough game. I really like the design so far though, the EA into and the music is really jazzy, and I feel like if I get any further in the game I'm really going to have a blast, even more so than where I am right now.

I guess if there's anything I'd fix with the game, it's that you can't seem to get it to recognize your XBox360 controller. I mean DANG, I'm not the only one with the problem, patch this already so we can keep playing, Ubisoft! ;)

All in all, I wouldn't recommend this game though. It's really short and so far all I've been able to do is enter the options and that's about it.

I'm sure the rest of the game is great though, but it might be too hard for noobs like me. I mean, if I can't get any further than that, just two minutes into the game, I guess I'm going to have a really hard time in the later parts.

Anyway that's it for my review. Oh, and here's some extra points:

Graphics 4/5 - Crisp and really great, iconic design. Good intro animation.
Sound 4/5 - it gets repetitive after a while, and there only seems to be one song so far, but it's catchy!
Plot 3/5 - The game's really got me stoked to find out what those little things flying into the EA symbol in the beginning are.
Controls 1/5 - While technically I haven't been able to play with my controller yet, the mouse can open menus really well!
Challenge 5/5 - Only play this if you are a PRO! I mean it!
Overall  3.5/5 - Hopefully there's going to be a LP that'll show me how to get past the control puzzle soon.

9074306.review: I love this game! The graphics are amazing, and the platforming is the best I've ever seen. Seriously, it's awesome and challenging, and is really fun when played on co-op. Unlocking characters and costumes are awesome too!

9007254.review:
Divertido jogo estilo plataforma, com sólida jogabilidade e possibilidade de jogar a campanha completa em modo cooperativo. Não há enredo nenhum, simplesmente um conceito apresentado o início do jogo e final dos níveis.

O jogo possui bonita arte cartunizada, com personagens de traços desengonçados e até mesmo engraçados, além de cenários bem coloridos e cheios de vida, que ao mesmo em tempo que enriquecem a paisagem, não causam excesso de elementos que poderiam atrapalhar o jogador.

Rayman conta com 10 níveis, que se subdividem em várias fases, e o grau de dificuldade cresce bastante conforme se avança na campanha. Existe a necessidade de coletar uma espécie de tokens durante as fases para que as seguintes sejam liberadas, mas não é nada abusivo, sendo perfeitamente possível terminar o jogo coletando apenas 3 dos 5 itens disponíveis, sem a necessidade de ficar repetindo fases  exaustivas vezes.

No entanto é legal coletar o máximo possível de tokens, porque eles liberam novos personagens jogáveis a serem escolhidos, além de desbloquearem uma fase bônus presente em cada um dos níveis.

No geral é um grande jogo de plataforma, engraçado, divertido, muito colorido e sem violência, ótimo para jogar com os filhos ou a namorada, como foi o meu caso. MUITO BOM  (8/10).

8835497.review:
[b]When gaming starts to feel like work... [/b]

... it's not a good sign for an in -my opinion- overhyped game.

Clearly the game has fancy and lovely graphics that will probably run on every machine. Then there are tight and responsive controls which should make a enjoyable platformer, but Rayman Origins lacks something that makes you want to see the next stage.
After three hours it seems that you've already seen everything and you will go through the same kind of levels in different scenarios again.
First platforming, then mosquito flying and in the end you will get a new skill. And when you have enough collectables you will go back to earlier worlds to race a treasure chest.
When I finally cleared all worlds and thought I was going to face the boss the game opened more passages to extended stages of the prior worlds.
And again I went through the same procedure again. Jumping, Flying and rescuing nymphs for the final assault. 
Overall it was very repetitive (gameplay, animation, screen and the end of every stage) and I literally was so bored that I almost didn't finish the game. 
Then there were some bugs that didn't make the game scroll to the new area when I went through portals or doors. The only solution was to restart the whole level again. 
Because the game becomes very challenging in the end ('Super Meat Boy'-esque),  this can be very frustrating and makes it definitely not a game for kids, although it's artdesign
and it's humor, which didn't really get me, makes you think so.

I really wanted to play Rayman Legends afterwards but my experience really made me reconsider. 

Unfortunally It's not a Mario or a DKCR (obviously the game's original) for PC ...

6/10

PS: The last levels were cool though ...

8827775.review:
Fun platformer for a reasonable price

I have played a couple of the previous Rayman games but only breifly and didn't find them particuarly engaging.

I picked this one up during the holiday sale (2013) for fairly cheap because I thought it would be a good game to play with my 4 year old son. It didn't take long for me to get hooked on this great game. Wonderful animations, artwork and music all come together to make this one of the best 2D platformers I have had the pleasure of playing. The Co-op is also fantastic in that it allows a seasoned gamer play with a 4 year old and not get held up, in fact, the co-op is set up in such a way that having an inexperienced gamer can still assist in progressing through the game.

Graphics:
Graphically the game is flawless running at full HD and it runs great even on my work laptop with Intel graphics. The animations are smooth, artwork is amazing and the controls are responsive and natural.

Sound:
The game has a great sound track and the sounds are interesting and varied.

Overall the game is great, the only issue I have is with the steam overlay, it is best to disable it in the game properties. If you bring up the overlay in game it can cause a player to join and run to the left which can be a real pain.

8720161.review:
Ce jeu est un véritable bijou : un must have!

Les graphismes sont dignes d'un dessin animé de Dysney.
Les animations sont drôles et exagérées, dans le style cartoon.
Le level design est très inspiré : le jeu alternera de la plateforme, des niveaux de shoot them up à scrolling horizontal, des courses poursuites pour attraper des coffres au trésor, des niveaux bonus, des combats de boss, etc...
La musique signée Christophe Heral suit toujours l'action, variée et très rythmée. Le studio d'Ubisoft Montpellier a l'habitude de travailler avec cet artiste et le résultat est excellent!

La durée de vie est d'une bonne trentaine d'heures. Il y a à la fois beaucoup de niveaux et une rejouabilité importante car le jeu encourage à refaire les niveaux pour améliorer le score s'il n'est pas suffisant, ou pour arriver à traverser le niveau dans un temps très serré, et toujours dans le but de débloquer les niveaux de course au trésor.

Le jeu ne parait jamais trop long car au fur et à mesure il s'enrichit de nouvelles possibilités, au début au saute, puis on apprend à courrir, à coller des baffes, à planer dans les airs, à nager sous l'eau, à courir sur les murs etc... plus les niveaux avancent et plus le gameplay sera riche.

Grâce à l'utilisation de la 2D le gameplay est très précis, ce qui permet au jeu d'être exigeant.
Ce n'est pas parce que le style est enfantin que le jeu est facile, loin de là!
Pourtant le jeu pardonnera les erreurs grâce aux nombreux points de sauvegarde.
Le niveau de difficulté diminue aussi avec le nombre de joueurs : en coop il suffit de mettre une bafe à un perso pour le ressusciter.
Si vous doutez de l'efficacité du mode coop, allez sur Youtube et tapez "farfromsubtle rayman origins", vous verrez par vous même l'ambiance d'une course effrénée pour attraper plus de Lums que les potes en leur faisant des coups de pute dès que l'occasion se présente. Une sorte de compétition dans le mode coop, c'est brillant!

Bref, c'est le sans faute pour Rayman Origins.
On aimerait tellement que les gros studios comme Ubisoft se consacrent d'avantage à créer ce style de jeu où tout fonctionne pour rendre le jeu amusant (voire jouissif) plutôt que de privilégier toujours des gros jeux en 3D dont les idées sont copiées de jeux déjà existants et dont on voit immédiatement que tout le budget a été englouti dans la technique...

8419209.review: Excellent multiplayer 2D platformer.  Unlike many in this genre, players won't bounce off of each other, or generally get in each other's way.  (Though you can hit each other, which may be used to assist in finding the secrets/exploration.)  There are no limits to lives - as long as any single player is still alive, the other players can continue.  You only need to restart the level if everyone dies at the same time.  This makes it possible for widely varying skill levels to still have fun together.  The skill progression is also nicely balanced - you aren't given new abilities until the prior abilities have been deeply explored and mastered.

A masterpiece from the geniuses at Ubisoft Montpellier, Rayman Origins boasts a gorgeous art style, slick controls, clever level design and a fantastic soundtrack. While the story's as barebones as it gets (you're a limbless guy and/or his friends! go kill some evil shit!) everything else about the game more than makes up for that. 8162566.review:
25/25 Gameplay
9/10 Fairness
10/10 Sound
15/15 Graphics
15/15 Controls
13/15 Longness 
4/10 Multiplayer

Rayman Origins, the first remake of the Rayman games, is one of the best platformers I have ever seen. Why? Read this test to learn more!

First of all I want to talk about the atmosphere. You play in different worlds and their "Dark" World types. The worlds are completly different (Forrest, African, I won't spoiler more...) and have their own music and graphics. You see  Dust flying up in the African styled maps and after a time this even becomes a part of the Gameplay!
The Graphics are just awesome. Hand-made worlds create a feeling of really being in the Rayman World. Together with the fitting sounds and music, this creates a very good atmosphere.
Also: When I played the first levels of Rayman, it made me really happy. I played and was happy. I even had to stop myself from playing too much, because I did not want Rayman's adventure to go over too fast!

Now to the Fairness and sticked with that: The Controls. 
The Controls are intuitive and easy-to-learn. After some times, you get new abilities, which though do not make the game confusing. You understand them and they stay in your brain.
The game is pretty easy if you just want to play it through. You just have to get through the levels with the (sometimes not so many) checkpoints. But if you want a challenge, ok: Collect over 300, or even 350 points in the level, complete it with the best time possible or even find all of the hidden emoticons!
Anyways, sometimes the not so good spreaded checkpoints are a little annoying or the unlimate pro times in the time challengers mode. You have to complete the level in a certain time (may sometimes even be 3 minutes!) AND not die AND be as fast as somehow possible. This is sometimes annoying, but I mean: it is optional, so...

I already talked about the Gameplay a bit: Different worlds, different challenges, new abilities, time trial,...
The most fun though is exploring the level. If you just up in the "wrong" way that you should and then do a bit of this and that...Hey! There is a mini game for an emoticon! And if you try to just go under the collapsing bridge...50 points in a coin! Nice done, Ubisoft!
Also, you unlock new characters and racing levels with the emoticons. The characters are just for the optics, but the races are really fun! With the pursuit soundtrack you run behind a running Chest around a collapsing level, split up, come to him again, etc etc. It is just like a much better time trial mode! 

Anyways, the Longness is not so long if you just play the game through without secrets, time trials and so on. You can be through in 7 hours. If you do the time trials and the other stuff, Rayman can take like 25 hours. This is up to you. For this huge difference there is a minus in the points rating though...
The Multiplayer is the only thing I would critise in the game: You may play local Co Op, but there are no Local Co Op levels, and in a time in which everything is connected to the Internet, an Internet Multiplayer is actually a must-have...

TL;DR: If you want to play a platformer which makes you happy while exploring wonderful levels with atmospheric music, you should buy this game! Just if you need a Multiplayer at all costs though, you should think about getting the game.

Rayman Origins looks and plays really well. It's a great platformer. But...I'm in two minds about this one. And that's mostly due to the last set of levels I had to go through in the game. Maybe this is picky, but, that last set of levels really tarnished the experience for me. 

Example - You're running along a scrolling screen type setup with falling debris. Hopping from piece to piece when, you get slowed down for a moment. You get back on track, but, now the debris is further along and you can't reach it anymore. Even though, the edge of the screen hasn't caught up, you cannot recover and die. This is terrible level design as far as I'm concerned.

That above example happened so many times and it was rage inducing! In fact, sometimes you could be travelling along that same setup, making no mistakes and suddenly the platforms would slow down or go faster than normal for no good reason. Then it's fall to your death time again. AGGGHHHH!

However, as much as I've just written a bad overview above, I'm still going to recommend the game. The above only accounts for maybe 5% of the total experience. That and, I was forcing myself through till I beat it.

So, overall, it's a wonderful mix of platforming, shooting and just straight up goofy, cartoony goodness. This and Rayman Legends are really wonderful games for old school platforming. So, check it out if you're into that kind of thing!

1110771.review:
Rayman: Origins is a 2D side-scrolling, platforming adventure with full four-player local co-op.
Rayman accidentally started a war with the Livid Dead, the monsters lurking beneath the otherwise peaceful Glade of Dreams.
The protagonist must work his way through a series of themed stages, collecting floating objects called "Lums", and rescuing critters known as "Electoons" from hidden cages. Reaching certain Lum targets can earn extra "Electoons", which unlock new levels and characters.
Besides of jumping Rayman learns new skills such as hovering, swimming and shrinking, bringing a compelling variety to the action, and testing your dexterity to the limits.
On your way you have to cross floating platforms, dissolving platforms, platforms that twist and turn, that bounce you into the air or slowly fall and fade.
Rayman: Origins has impressive graphics, the backgrounds are beautifully drawn and has multiple layers of action.
The levels vary from familiar takes on platforming staples – cloud levels and underwater levels – to such oddities as a world based on didgeridoos.
Alongside the standard platforming levels, there are boss encounters, and scrolling shoot-'em-up challenges in which you leap on to a mosquito and fly through formations of angry birds and spiky puffer fish.
Rayman Origins features drop-in/drop-out cooperative play for up to four players at a time and as long as one of you stays alive to free injured players from bubbles in which they become trapped when hit, progress through a level remains possible.
Everywhere there is humour and whimsy, every screen a feast of bizarre scenery and weird inhabitants.
Rayman: Origins is one of the best platforming experiences you are going to have on Steam. The game is crafted with so much love, so much humor, and does so many things right, that it is impossible not to have a blast. It is definitly worth the money.

Sounds 8/10
Graphics 8/10
Gameplay 9/10
Atmosphere 9/10

As an avid Rayman player who played every single PC-installment, as well as the first two Raving Rabbids-games, this game made me almost cry tears of nostalgia.

This game has everything, and I repeat, EVERYTHING you want from a 2D-Rayman-game. 

- The artstyle is unlike anything you have seen in any of the previous installments, yet it naturally fits into Rayman's world. 

- The music does an amazing job of reinforcing the feel the worlds give you upon your first impression

- The difficulty of the game is never too easy and rises drastically in the end, with the last world being a serious challenge for every Jump n Run-fan

- The humor is fantastic and, again, fits perfectly in the game without being awkward/repelling at all.


Any old Rayman fans who were sceptical should definitely buy this game (and probably Rayman Legends as well, while they're at it), because this is the most fun I've had in ages playing a 2D-JnR-game. Definitely worth every cent!
